awd_titl_txt: A fresh look into the high-resolution Lyman-alpha forest: searching for deviations from the standard model for the intergalactic medium and measuring better its thermal history
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to develop a complete model of the evolution of the Universe, we need to understand how all the components have evolved.  One component that is not well understood is the origin and evolution of the material between galaxies - the intergalactic medium (IGM). The goal of this research is to combine an analysis of very high quality quasar spectra with theoretical considerations to answer open questions about the evolution of the IGM.  Broader impacts of the work include mentoring of underrepresented freshman undergraduates, training of a graduate student, and a series of public lectures in the Seattle area to astronomical societies and public schools.

The work will address several important issues concerning studies of the Lyman-alpha forest, including a test of the standard picture of IGM evolution. By combining high-resolution quasar spectra with numerical simulations, the objective is to reconcile the existing observations with theoretical expectations for the Lyman-alpha forest.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project involved developing better theories for understanding the intergalactic medium and applying new statistics to test these theories using observations of hydrogen absorption from the intergalactic medium (IGM). Hydrogen absorption is our primary diagnostic of the low density IGM.  Key results and outcomes include:

This project performed measurements of new hydrogen absorption statistics, expanding beyond the statistic the IGM field has most concentrated on, the power spectrum of hydrogen Lyman-alpha line absorption.  We measured the power spectrum of an unexplored hydrogen absorption line, Lyman-beta, and its cross power spectrum with Lyman-alpha forest using data from the Very Large Telescope.  The Lyman-beta line has allowed us to more cleanly measure the temperature of the IGM. Our measurements are indicating a steep relation between temperature and density in the IGM (with a somewhat hotter than expected normalization), although these surprising temperatures may instead indicate a breakdown of our standard model for the intergalactic medium (as could occur from more-efficient-than-expected galactic feedback).  See an attached figure that illustrates this measurement, which we are still in the process of interpreting.  In addition, we started investigating a statistic that correlates the large-scale fluctuations in the Lyman-alpha forest to the small-scale variance and are presently working through the analysis.  This statistic provides another test of our standard model for the IGM.

This project additionally supported research, which has already resulted in highly-cited papers, on constraining warm and fuzzy dark matter models using intergalactic hydrogen Lyman-alpha absorption.    Our hydrogen Lyman-alpha forest measurements provide the tightest existing constraints on these dark matter models (see attached plot for our warm dark matter mass constraints). Related to this, this award supported work on a novel constraint on fuzzy dark matter models from the Lyman-alpha forest in the limit that the fuzzy dark matter is established by symmetry breaking after inflation.

This award also supported the development of models for understanding the statistics of IGM hydrogen absorption. We developed a semi-analytic model for this absorption based on the absorption line decomposition and the halo model, as well as a more complete understanding of what sets the temperature of the IGM.  Our semi-analytic model allows us to better understand how the properties of the IGM shape the statistics of hydrogen absorption, which has been helpful for developing statistics for isolating properties of interest. Further, the temperature is the ingredient in the standard model for the Lyman-alpha forest that was the most uncertain prior to our work.  

Finally, the PI authored  a review article on the intergalactic medium in the Annual Review in Astronomy and Astrophysics.  This work aids those beginning research in this field as well as astronomers/physicists in other fields learning this topic.  

The broader impacts of this project consisted of training students and giving public presentations.  We trained two groups in the University of Washington Pre-Major in Astronomy Program (preMAP), which aims to engage freshmen from underrepresented groups in STEM in a quarter-long research project.  Furthermore, this award supported the supervision of four undergraduates in research, particularly with summer internships (many of whom were previously our preMAP students).  One undergraduate was supervised by the project PI for four years and recently started a physics Ph.D. program.  This award also supported the training of two graduate students for two quarters and of a postdoctoral researcher for 2.5 years.  The postdoctoral researcher funded by this award advanced to a prestigious five-year postdoctoral fellowship at Cambridge University.   Finally, we have given approximately ten public talks over the award period on topics related to this research at venues in the Seattle area.
